slides.title: IAM Fundamentals
slides.content:
# Identity & Access Management ğŸ”

Control who can access what in your cloud.

## Core Concepts

### Authentication (AuthN)
- **Who are you?**
- Verify identity
- Usernames, passwords, MFA, keys

### Authorization (AuthZ)
- **What can you do?**
- Permissions and access levels
- Roles and policies

## IAM Components

| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Users** | Individual identities |
| **Groups** | Collections of users |
| **Roles** | Temporary credentials |
| **Policies** | Permission definitions |
| **Service Accounts** | Non-human identities |

## Principle of Least Privilege
```
âœ… Grant minimum required permissions
âœ… Start with no access, add as needed
âœ… Regularly review and revoke unused access
âŒ Never use wildcard (*) in production
âŒ Never share credentials
```

> âš ï¸ **Security First:** 80% of cloud breaches involve IAM misconfigurations!

slides.title: IAM Policies Deep Dive
slides.content:
# IAM Policies ğŸ“œ

JSON documents that define permissions.

## Policy Structure (AWS Example)
```json
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "AllowS3Read",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "s3:GetObject",
        "s3:ListBucket"
      ],
      "Resource": [
        "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket",
        "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket/*"
      ],
      "Condition": {
        "IpAddress": {
          "aws:SourceIp": "10.0.0.0/8"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

## Policy Elements

| Element | Purpose | Example |
|---------|---------|--------|
| **Effect** | Allow or Deny | `"Allow"` |
| **Action** | API operations | `"s3:GetObject"` |
| **Resource** | Target resources | `"arn:aws:s3:::*"` |
| **Condition** | When to apply | IP, time, MFA |

## Policy Types
- **Identity-based:** Attached to users/roles
- **Resource-based:** Attached to resources
- **Permission boundaries:** Maximum permissions
- **SCPs:** Organization-level controls

slides.title: IAM Best Practices
slides.content:
# IAM Security Best Practices âœ…

Secure your cloud from day one.

## Must-Do Practices

### 1. Enable MFA Everywhere
```bash
# Enforce MFA in policy
{
  "Condition": {
    "Bool": {
      "aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent": "true"
    }
  }
}
```

### 2. Use Roles, Not Keys
```bash
# Bad: Hardcoded credentials
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=AKIA...
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=...

# Good: Assume role
aws sts assume-role --role-arn arn:aws:iam::...
```

### 3. Rotate Credentials
- Rotate access keys every 90 days
- Use temporary credentials when possible
- Automate rotation with secrets managers

### 4. Monitor & Audit
```
CloudTrail â†’ Log all API calls
CloudWatch â†’ Alert on suspicious activity
Access Analyzer â†’ Find public resources
```

## IAM Checklist
- âœ… Root account has MFA
- âœ… Root account not used daily
- âœ… Password policy enforced
- âœ… No inline policies
- âœ… Regular access reviews
- âœ… Unused credentials removed

slides.title: VPC Introduction
slides.content:
# Virtual Private Cloud ğŸŒ

Your own isolated network in the cloud.

## What is a VPC?
- Logically isolated network
- You control IP ranges, subnets, routing
- Secure boundary for resources
- Foundation for cloud networking

## VPC Components

| Component | Purpose |
|-----------|--------|
| **CIDR Block** | IP address range |
| **Subnets** | Network segments |
| **Route Tables** | Traffic routing rules |
| **Internet Gateway** | Internet access |
| **NAT Gateway** | Outbound-only internet |
| **Security Groups** | Instance firewalls |
| **NACLs** | Subnet firewalls |

## CIDR Notation
```
10.0.0.0/16  â†’ 65,536 IP addresses
10.0.1.0/24  â†’ 256 IP addresses
10.0.1.0/28  â†’ 16 IP addresses

/16 = Large VPC
/24 = Typical subnet
/28 = Small subnet
```

## Default vs Custom VPC
- **Default:** Created automatically, public by default
- **Custom:** You design everything, recommended for production

slides.content:

Organize and route traffic within your VPC.

### Public Subnet
- Has route to Internet Gateway
- Resources get public IPs
- Web servers, load balancers

### Private Subnet
- No direct internet access

slides.title: Security Groups vs NACLs
slides.content:
# VPC Security Layers ğŸ”’

Multiple layers of network security.

## Security Groups (Instance Level)

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Scope** | Instance/ENI level |
| **State** | Stateful (return traffic auto-allowed) |
| **Rules** | Allow rules only |
| **Evaluation** | All rules evaluated |

```
Inbound Rules:
- TCP 22 from 10.0.0.0/8 (SSH)
- TCP 443 from 0.0.0.0/0 (HTTPS)

Outbound Rules:
- All traffic to 0.0.0.0/0 (default)
```

## Network ACLs (Subnet Level)

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Scope** | Subnet level |
| **State** | Stateless (must allow return traffic) |
| **Rules** | Allow and Deny rules |
| **Evaluation** | Rules processed in order |

```
Inbound:
100 ALLOW TCP 443 from 0.0.0.0/0
200 DENY  TCP 22  from 0.0.0.0/0
*   DENY  ALL     from 0.0.0.0/0
```

## Comparison
```
Internet â†’ NACL (Subnet) â†’ Security Group (Instance) â†’ EC2
              â”‚                    â”‚
           Stateless            Stateful
         Allow + Deny          Allow only
```

slides.title: Network Load Balancer
slides.content:
# Network Load Balancer (NLB) ğŸš€

Ultra-high performance Layer 4 load balancing.

## Key Features
- Millions of requests/second
- Ultra-low latency (~100Î¼s)
- Static IP per AZ
- TCP/UDP/TLS support
- Preserves source IP

## When to Use NLB

| Use Case | Why NLB |
|----------|--------|
| Gaming | Low latency |
| IoT | TCP connections |
| VoIP | UDP traffic |
| Financial | Performance |
| Static IPs | Required endpoint |

## NLB vs ALB

| Feature | ALB | NLB |
|---------|-----|-----|
| Layer | 7 (HTTP) | 4 (TCP/UDP) |
| Latency | ~400Î¼s | ~100Î¼s |
| Static IP | No | Yes |
| WebSockets | Yes | Yes |
| SSL Offload | Yes | Yes |
| Path Routing | Yes | No |

## Configuration
```bash
# Create NLB
aws elbv2 create-load-balancer \
  --name my-nlb \
  --type network \
  --subnets subnet-abc subnet-def

# Create TCP listener
aws elbv2 create-listener \
  --load-balancer-arn $NLB_ARN \
  --protocol TCP \
  --port 80 \
  --default-actions Type=forward,TargetGroupArn=$TG_ARN
```

slides.title: Scaling Policies
slides.content:
# Scaling Policies ğŸ“Š

Define when and how to scale.

## Policy Types

### 1. Target Tracking
```
Metric: Average CPU Utilization
Target: 50%

CPU > 50% â†’ Add instances
CPU < 50% â†’ Remove instances
```
- Simple and automatic
- AWS manages the math
- Best for most cases

### 2. Step Scaling
```
CPU 50-70% â†’ +1 instance
CPU 70-90% â†’ +2 instances
CPU > 90%  â†’ +3 instances
```
- More control
- Different actions for different thresholds

### 3. Simple Scaling
```
Alarm triggers â†’ Add/Remove X instances
Wait for cooldown
```
- Legacy approach
- Single adjustment

### 4. Scheduled Scaling
```
# Scale up every weekday at 9 AM
aws autoscaling put-scheduled-update-group-action \
  --scheduled-action-name morning-scale-up \
  --auto-scaling-group-name my-asg \
  --recurrence "0 9 * * MON-FRI" \
  --desired-capacity 10
```

## Cooldown Period
- Wait time after scaling activity
- Prevents thrashing
- Default: 300 seconds

## Versioning
```bash
# Create new version
aws ec2 create-launch-template-version \
  --launch-template-id lt-0abc123 \
  --source-version 1 \
  --launch-template-data '{"InstanceType":"t3.large"}'

# Set default version

  --launch-template-id lt-0abc123 \
```

slides.title: Creating Auto-Scaling Groups
slides.content:
# Auto-Scaling Group Setup ğŸš€

Create and configure an ASG.

## AWS CLI
```bash
# Create ASG
aws autoscaling create-auto-scaling-group \
  --auto-scaling-group-name my-asg \
  --launch-template LaunchTemplateName=my-template,Version='$Latest' \
  --min-size 2 \
  --max-size 10 \
  --desired-capacity 3 \
  --vpc-zone-identifier "subnet-abc,subnet-def" \
  --target-group-arns $ALB_TG_ARN \
  --health-check-type ELB \
  --health-check-grace-period 300

# Add target tracking policy
aws autoscaling put-scaling-policy \
  --auto-scaling-group-name my-asg \
  --policy-name cpu-target-tracking \
  --policy-type TargetTrackingScaling \
  --target-tracking-configuration '{
    "TargetValue": 50.0,
    "PredefinedMetricSpecification": {
      "PredefinedMetricType": "ASGAverageCPUUtilization"
    }
  }'
```

## Health Check Types
| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **EC2** | Instance status checks |
| **ELB** | Load balancer health checks |

## Instance Refresh
```bash
# Rolling update to new version
aws autoscaling start-instance-refresh \
  --auto-scaling-group-name my-asg \
  --preferences '{"MinHealthyPercentage": 90}'
```

slides.title: Horizontal vs Vertical Scaling
slides.content:
# Scaling Strategies ğŸ“

Two approaches to meeting demand.

## Horizontal Scaling (Scale Out/In)
```
Before:  [Server A]

After:   [Server A] [Server B] [Server C]
```
- Add more instances
- Distributed load
- Better for stateless apps
- Auto-Scaling friendly

## Vertical Scaling (Scale Up/Down)
```
Before:  [t3.small - 2 vCPU, 2GB]

After:   [t3.xlarge - 4 vCPU, 16GB]
```
- Increase instance size
- Simple but limited
- Requires downtime
- Upper limit exists

## Comparison

| Aspect | Horizontal | Vertical |
|--------|-----------|----------|
| Availability | High | Lower |
| Downtime | None | Required |
| Complexity | Higher | Lower |
| Cost | Pay-as-grow | Jumps |
| Limit | Virtually none | Hardware limit |

## Best Practice
```

â”‚ Design for horizontal scaling           â”‚
```

slides.title: Predictive Scaling
slides.content:
# Predictive Scaling ğŸ”®

Scale proactively based on patterns.

## How It Works
- Analyzes historical traffic
- Uses machine learning
- Predicts future demand
- Scales BEFORE needed

## Comparison
```
Reactive Scaling:
  Demand â†‘ â†’ Detect â†’ Scale â†’ Catch up
  (Users experience slowdown)

Predictive Scaling:
  Predict â†’ Scale â†’ Demand â†‘ â†’ Ready!
  (Users see no difference)
```

## Enable Predictive Scaling
```bash
aws autoscaling put-scaling-policy \
  --auto-scaling-group-name my-asg \
  --policy-name predictive-scaling \
  --policy-type PredictiveScaling \
  --predictive-scaling-configuration '{
    "MetricSpecifications": [{
      "TargetValue": 50,
      "PredefinedMetricPairSpecification": {
        "PredefinedMetricType": "ASGCPUUtilization"
      }
    }],
    "Mode": "ForecastAndScale",
    "SchedulingBufferTime": 300
  }'
```

## Modes
| Mode | Behavior |
|------|----------|
| **ForecastOnly** | Generates forecast, no action |
| **ForecastAndScale** | Scales based on forecast |

> ğŸ’¡ **Best for:** Regular patterns like business hours traffic!

slides.content:
# Cost Optimization Strategies ğŸ’°

Optimize spending across core services.

## IAM Costs
- IAM itself is free!
- Reduce human access â†’ Use roles
- Centralize with AWS Organizations

## VPC Costs
| Service | Cost |
|---------|------|
| VPC | Free |
| NAT Gateway | $0.045/hr + data |
| VPN | $0.05/hr |
| Transit Gateway | $0.05/hr/attachment |

**Savings:** Use NAT instances for dev/test

## Load Balancer Costs
- ALB: $0.0225/hr + LCU charges
- NLB: $0.0225/hr + LCU charges

**Savings:** Right-size, use fewer LBs

## Auto-Scaling Savings
- Scale in during low demand
- Use Spot instances (up to 90% off)
- Mix On-Demand + Spot

```bash
# Mixed instances policy
"MixedInstancesPolicy": {
  "InstancesDistribution": {
    "OnDemandBaseCapacity": 2,
    "OnDemandPercentageAboveBaseCapacity": 20,
    "SpotAllocationStrategy": "capacity-optimized"
  }
}
```

> ğŸ’¡ **Best Practice:** Review monthly, optimize quarterly!
